South Carolina

Unto the Worthy Gentlemen Members of the St. Andrews Club Assembled at their annual Anniversary -- 30th November 1769  

The Petition of Isabell Black a Native of Perth in Scotland

Most Humbly Sheweth

That your poor petitioner having most Unfortunately for your petitioner to be married to a Soldier in the Fusiliers who laying aside all Conjugall [conjugal] Affection and fatherly regard discarded me and left me and a helpless Infant destitute of everything even of Cloaths [clothes] or Covering for either, your humble petitioner having one Earnest desire to go to her native Country to her friends there humbly requests you would be pleased out of your Abundant goodness to grant your petitioner some small relief to provide some Necessarys in this unclement [inclement] Season for Cloaths etc. and that you would be also pleased out of the abundance of your goodness to procure a passage to Scotland for her and her Child --

May it therefore please you to take this your humble petitioners case into your most serious Consideration and to grant such relief as to you may seem meet And your petitioner is in duty ever bound to pray et cetera

Isabella Black [signature of applicant]
Charles Town
28th Nov. 1769
